definitions: steal goods from a place or person typically using force during war
take material possessions by force often in a violent or destructive way
examples: Pirates plundered ships along the trade routes
The invading army plundered the conquered city
Thieves plundered the museum of priceless artifacts
Vikings plundered coastal villages for centuries

definitions: divide or cause to divide into two sharply contrasting groups or opinions
restrict the vibrations of light waves to one direction making them aligned
examples: The controversial issue polarized public opinion completely
Social media tends to polarize political discussions
These sunglasses polarize light to reduce glare
The filter polarizes light waves for clearer images

definitions: think about something carefully especially before making a decision or conclusion
examples: She pondered the job offer for several days
Scientists ponder the mysteries of the universe

definitions: depict someone or something in a work of art or literature
describe or represent someone or something in a particular way using words
examples: The artist portrayed her subject with remarkable sensitivity
The film portrays life in medieval times
Media often portrays teenagers as rebellious and moody
The biography portrays him as a complex character

definitions: spring forward suddenly to attack or seize something especially as prey
take swift action to take advantage of an opportunity or mistake
examples: The cat pounced on the unsuspecting mouse
The eagle pounced from high above
Investors pounced on the undervalued stock immediately
She pounced on his grammatical error

definitions: come before something in time or order happening earlier
go in front of or ahead of someone or something physically
examples: The Bronze Age preceded the Iron Age
A brief introduction will precede the main presentation
Security guards preceded the president into the building
The parade was preceded by police motorcycles

definitions: cause an event or situation to happen suddenly especially something bad
cause a substance to be deposited in solid form from solution
examples: His resignation precipitated a leadership crisis
The scandal precipitated the company's downfall
Adding acid will precipitate the dissolved minerals
Cold temperatures precipitate sugar from the syrup

definitions: make someone liable or inclined to a specified attitude action or condition
examples: Genetics can predispose people to certain diseases
His upbringing predisposed him to distrust authority

definitions: take action to prevent an anticipated event from happening by acting first
replace a scheduled broadcast with one considered more important
examples: The company preempted competitors by launching first
Military strikes preempted the enemy's attack plans
Breaking news preempted regular television programming
The presidential address preempted the game show

definitions: write directions for the preparation and use of medicine for patient
state authoritatively or as a rule that an action should be carried out
examples: The doctor prescribed antibiotics for the infection
Only licensed physicians can prescribe certain medications
Company policy prescribes specific safety procedures
The law prescribes severe penalties for fraud

definitions: be in the position of authority in a meeting or gathering
examples: The chief justice will preside over the trial
She presided at the board meeting

definitions: suppose that something is the case based on probability without proof
be arrogantly confident of something or take liberties beyond what is proper
examples: I presume you've already eaten dinner
The court presumes innocence until proven guilty
Don't presume to tell me how to do my job
He presumed on their friendship too often

definitions: prove more powerful or superior in a struggle or conflict
be widespread or current in a particular area or time
examples: Justice will prevail in the end
Our team prevailed despite being outnumbered
These customs still prevail in rural areas
Cooler temperatures prevail during autumn months

definitions: announce officially or publicly in a formal or ceremonial way
declare something one considers important with due emphasis
examples: The mayor proclaimed a day of celebration
The president proclaimed a national emergency
She proclaimed her innocence to anyone who would listen
They proclaimed their love from the rooftops

definitions: obtain something especially with care effort or difficulty often for someone else
examples: The agent procured tickets to the sold-out show
It's difficult to procure these rare ingredients

definitions: claim openly that one has a quality or feeling especially falsely
affirm one's faith in or allegiance to a religion or principles
examples: He professed complete ignorance of the incident
She professed to be an expert in finance
They profess Christianity but rarely attend church
The organization professes dedication to environmental causes

definitions: extend the duration of something making it last longer than expected
examples: Medical advances help prolong human life significantly
Don't prolong the meeting with unnecessary discussions

definitions: spread and promote an idea theory or knowledge to many people
breed specimens of a plant or animal by natural processes
examples: Social media helps propagate information rapidly worldwide
They work to propagate democratic values globally
Gardeners propagate plants through cuttings and seeds
These bacteria propagate quickly in warm conditions

definitions: push or drive something forward with force physically
drive or push someone into a particular situation or state
examples: Jet engines propel the aircraft through the sky
The swimmer's powerful strokes propelled her forward
Ambition propelled him to the top of his profession
The scandal propelled the issue into public debate

definitions: institute legal proceedings against a person or organization for criminal behavior
continue a course of action with a view to its completion
examples: The state will prosecute anyone who breaks this law
The attorney prosecuted the case brilliantly
They prosecuted the war with great determination
Scientists prosecute their research despite setbacks

definitions: succeed in material terms becoming financially successful and wealthy
flourish physically or thrive in favorable conditions
examples: The business prospered under new management
Hard work helped the family prosper
Plants prosper in this fertile soil
The colony prospered despite initial hardships

definitions: lay oneself flat on the ground face downward in submission
reduce to extreme physical or emotional weakness
examples: Worshippers prostrate themselves before the altar
He prostrated himself at the emperor's feet
The illness left her prostrate with exhaustion
Grief prostrated him for several weeks

definitions: extend beyond or above a surface projecting outward from something else
examples: Sharp rocks protrude from the cliff face
His front teeth protrude slightly when he smiles

definitions: stimulate or give rise to a reaction or emotion in someone
deliberately make someone annoyed or angry by doing something
examples: The speech provoked widespread debate about immigration
Her research provoked new thinking on the subject
Stop trying to provoke your little brother
His comments were meant to provoke a response

definitions: move around quietly and secretly especially in search of prey or opportunity
examples: Tigers prowl through the jungle at night
Burglars prowled the neighborhood looking for targets

definitions: trim a tree shrub or bush by cutting away dead or overgrown parts
reduce the extent of something by removing unnecessary elements
examples: Gardeners prune rose bushes in early spring
You should prune fruit trees annually
The editor pruned unnecessary words from the manuscript
Companies often prune their product lines

definitions: inquire too inquisitively into a person's private affairs
move or open something with a lever or similar tool
examples: Neighbors love to pry into each other's business
Don't pry into matters that don't concern you
Use a crowbar to pry open the crate
He pried the lid off with a screwdriver

definitions: make something widely known to the public through various media channels
examples: The company publicized its new product through social media
They hired a firm to publicize the event

definitions: reduce to fine particles or powder by crushing or grinding
defeat utterly or destroy completely in a competition or conflict
examples: The machine pulverizes rocks into fine sand
Pulverize the spices before adding them
Our team pulverized the opposition forty to zero
The criticism pulverized his self-confidence

definitions: strike repeatedly with fists or a blunt object typically hard
examples: The boxer pummeled his opponent against the ropes
Hail pummeled the roof during the storm

definitions: insert punctuation marks in written text to clarify meaning
occur at intervals throughout a continuing event or state
examples: Remember to punctuate your sentences correctly
The editor punctuated the manuscript carefully
Bursts of laughter punctuated the serious discussion
Thunder punctuated the steady rain

definitions: remove unwanted people or elements from an organization or group
physically cleanse or empty something of impurities or unwanted matter
examples: The dictator purged the military of disloyal officers
They purged outdated files from the system
The treatment helps purge toxins from your body
Purge the pipes before winter arrives

definitions: remove contaminants or unwanted elements from something making it pure
examples: Water treatment plants purify drinking water daily
Fire was thought to purify corrupted souls

definitions: steal something especially in a breach of trust in circumstances
examples: Someone purloined my lunch from the office refrigerator
The secretary purloined funds from company accounts

definitions: appear or claim to be or do something especially falsely
examples: The document purports to be an official decree
He purports to be an expert on the subject

definitions: follow someone or something in order to catch or attack them
seek to achieve or attain a goal over a long period
examples: Police pursued the suspects through city streets
The hunter pursued the deer into the forest
She pursued a career in medicine
They pursue excellence in everything they do

definitions: feel or show fear or apprehension drawing back in fear
examples: She quailed at the thought of public speaking
The soldiers quailed before the enemy's advance

definitions: shake or tremble especially from instability fear or cold
examples: The ground quaked during the earthquake
He quaked with fear at the sight

definitions: isolate a person animal or place from others to prevent spread of disease
examples: The government quarantined travelers for fourteen days
We must quarantine infected plants immediately

definitions: have an angry argument or disagreement typically about trivial matters
examples: The siblings quarrel over toys constantly
Don't quarrel with me about such small things

definitions: reject or void something especially by legal procedure as invalid
put an end to or suppress something forcefully and completely
examples: The judge quashed the indictment
The court quashed his conviction on appeal
The government quashed the rebellion quickly
Management quashed rumors of layoffs

definitions: put an end to a rebellion or other disorder typically by force
subdue or reduce strong or unpleasant feelings making them calm
examples: Troops were sent to quell the riots
Police quelled the disturbance within hours
The medication helps quell nausea
Her reassuring words quelled his anxiety

definitions: satisfy one's thirst by drinking sufficient liquid
extinguish a fire or light by dousing with water
examples: Cold water will quench your thirst quickly
Nothing quenches thirst better than lemonade
Firefighters worked to quench the flames
Rain quenched the forest fire

definitions: ask a question about something especially to express doubt
question the accuracy or validity of a statement or finding
examples: Students may query the professor after class
I need to query this charge on my bill
Auditors will query any unusual expenses
Don't query my decision on this matter

definitions: make or become faster in movement pace or occurrence
stimulate or become stimulated giving or restoring life or vigor
examples: Her pulse quickened when she saw him
We need to quicken the pace of development
Spring rain quickens the dormant seeds
His interest quickened as she explained

definitions: tremble or shake with a slight rapid motion from emotion or cold
examples: Her voice quivered with emotion
The leaves quiver in the breeze

definitions: test the knowledge of someone by asking them questions informally
examples: The teacher will quiz students on vocabulary tomorrow
Parents often quiz children about their day

definitions: repeat or copy the exact words from a text or speech
give someone an estimated price for a job or service
examples: She likes to quote Shakespeare in conversation
The article quotes several expert opinions
The contractor will quote a price for renovations
Can you quote me a rate for shipping
